para.inline: CSIRO Riverside Corporate Park, North Ryde, NSWâJoint Research Complex for CSIRO Molecular Science and Food Science Australia (Eighth report of 1999)
CSIRO Division of Building Construction and Engineering Development Works at Riverside Corporate Park, North Ryde, NSW (Ninth report of 1999)

speech.para: Madam President, the reports which I have just tabled concern proposals to construct new facilities for the CSIRO's Division of Molecular Science and Food Science Australia and CSIRO's Division of Building Construction and Engineering Development.
Both are to be constructed at Riverside Corporate Park at North Ryde in Sydney.

The Riverside Corporate Park contains the largest aggregation of CSIRO research activities in New South Wales. Long term planning envisages development of the corporate park, within CSIRO precincts, to provide modern research facilities.

Land surplus to CSIRO requirements has been developed and infrastructure and site services have been upgraded or replaced for sale to private sector companies. Further rationalisation and consolidation of CSIRO facilities is planned.
The estimated out turn cost of both proposals is $59 million dollars.

The Committee has recommended that the works should proceed as proposed.The first report, the eighth of 1999, concerns the construction of a new joint complex for the Division of Molecular Science and Food Science Australia. This will replace predominantly old and substandard existing facilities at North Ryde that are now inadequate for conducting modern scientific research.

The new facilities will provide accommodation for 220 Food Science Australia and Division of Molecular Science staff plus long-term visitors and students. Facilities will also include amenities, support services and infrastructure which will be shared among all CSIRO divisions within the central precinct of Riverside Corporate Park.
The estimated cost of this proposal is $49 million dollars.

By way of background, Food Science Australia and the Division of Molecular Science undertake wide-ranging strategic and applied research for industries which play a vital role in the continued economic growth of Australia. Both Divisions are housed in facilities which are inadequate and cannot be adapted to contemporary and future research requirements. North Ryde is regarded as an ideal location for both organisations which are required to interact with companies and universities located in the Sydney area.

The Committee has concluded that a need exists for the provision of modern research facilities for the two Divisions which would benefit from being collocated. In terms of the scope of the proposal, the Committee has concluded that it will provide both Divisions with much needed modern research laboratories and ancillary facilities. The extent of the complex can be justified being necessary to meet current and future requirements. CSIRO staff were involved in some detailed planning of the proposed joint complex.

A noteworthy feature is the location and height of the Joint Research Centre. These will combine to create a strong architectural statement whose immediate impact will be tempered by the setback from Delhi Road and tree plantings. The question of the profile and heights of exhaust stacks arose during the inquiry and the Committee has recommended that these features should be re-examined to reduce their visual impact.
As is normally the case, CSIRO consulted widely with State and local government planning authorities in order to meet planning requirements.

In relation to the wider coporate park, the Committee has concluded that CSIRO has implemented extensive initiatives to minimise the environmental impact of the development of the corporate park site. These measures include extensive stormwater management and the provision of a substantial portion of land as a flora and fauna reserve.

The second report, the Committee's ninth of 1999, concerns the replacement of predominantly old and substandard facilities with new state-of-the-art accommodation for the construction materials laboratory and fire technology complex of the CSIRO's Division of Building Construction and Engineering.

The facilities proposed in this stage of the replacement program will accommodate 70 research and support staff and comprise modern research facilities and management and administration offices, together with industrial scale technical areas and testing bays. More specifically, the development will include:
. Fire Testing FacilitiesâTechnical and Testing bays and support areas;
. Structural Fire and Testing facility;
. Reaction to Fire Materials facility;
. Fire Safety Performance Evaluation facility;
. Construction Materials Facilitiesâprocess bays and laboratories; and
. Central Facilitiesâreception, meeting rooms, office and support areas.

Madam President, the Committee is satisfied that the proposed development is necessary in order for CSIRO Building Construction and Engineering to continue to meet its objectives of supporting, advancing and improving the operation of industries relating to the built environment. The Construction Materials research team, which provides strategic support to Australian concrete research, is currently housed in temporary laboratories at Riverside Corporate Park. It is essential that new and improved laboratories be built in order to support the growth in the important area of CSIRO research in advanced cementitious technology.

The Fire Science and Technology Laboratory enhances the competitiveness of Australian industry and public safety through performance prediction methods, measurement technologies and technical advances which result in improvements in the built environment.

Existing fire research and testing facilities are constraining the CSIRO's current capabilities and will not enable fulfilment of future local and international market needs. The proposed new facility will focus on new science capabilities in fire suppression technology, including methods of extinguishing large industrial fires such as the Longford gas fire and the fire at Coode Island in Victoria.

Madam President, while the Committee supports this proposed development it notes that some concerns have been raised by community groups about the likely adverse impacts of the development on the local environment. The Committee took evidence from these groups as well as from various local and State authorities and is satisfied that the CSIRO has planned and will implement numerous conservation measures which will ensure the preservation of a healthy local environment.

The Committee has recommended that the CSIRO continue to supervise development works to ensure the local environment is fully protected, and furthermore that the CSIRO give community groups an opportunity to contribute their views to the environmental management plan currently being developed for this project.
Madam President, I commend these reports to the Senate.

Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

The purpose of this bill is to apply aspects of the Commonwealth's competitive neutrality policy to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC), which is a key Commonwealth statutory authority in the Government's integrated approach to promoting and supporting Australian exporters.

EFIC does this by providing a range of insurance and finance facilities where these are not normally provided by the private sector. It has had an important part to play in the Government's strong commitment to assisting Australian exporters during the Asian economic crisis, most notably through the National Interest Account facilities agreed to by Cabinet for Korea and Indonesia. More generally, EFIC support over the past five years has underpinned some $34.5 billion worth of exports to more than 150 countries and involved some 1,200 exporters, many of whom have been small and medium sized businesses.

As the Prime Minister announced in the Government's "Investing for Growth" statement in 1997, the Government has reviewed its ownership of EFIC and concluded that the interests of exporters are best served by a strong EFIC under existing ownership arrangements. EFIC's role during the Asian economic crisis has amply demonstrated the merits of this decision.

At the same time, the Commonwealth's competitive neutrality policy requires that government business activities do not have net competitive advantages over their private sector competitors simply as a result of their public ownership. EFIC's activities in the short-term insurance area potentially overlap with those of private insurers, although such an overlap does not occur in respect of EFIC's medium- to long-term activities. The Government is concerned to ensure that, to the extent possible, consistent with operating a viable business, EFIC does not enjoy a net competitive advantage. This accords with the Government's desire to foster the development of private sector insurers.

This bill therefore applies a debt neutrality charge, guarantee fee and tax-equivalent payments to EFIC's operations in the area of short-term insurance contracts. The bill also removes EFIC's current exemptions from the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 and Insurance Contracts Act 1984 in relation to such operations. These changes will assist in providing a more even competitive situation for the development of the private market.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âAt the request of Senator Carr, I move:

speech.para: That the Senate notes, with deep concern, the statement by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Chairman, Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, that, `Despite the gains in Indigenous education in the past three decades, Indigenous students lag behind other Australians by almost any measure of participation or attainment. The gap between rates of retention for non-Indigenous students compared with Indigenous students has increased and is expected to worsen.'

Mr Djerrkura's comments come as a result of a report commissioned and released by ATSIC; an independent analysis of the proposed changes to Abstudy. Before I go on to make some comments about Abstudy and the findings of that report, I want to put on record some figures which show the state of Aboriginal and indigenous education in this country. This is, I think, a record which is not only a national disgrace but also an international disgrace. The record of participation and attainment rates by indigenous students in this country leaves a lot to be desired, particularly because the current policies of this government do not seek to reverse the figures that I am about to read.

In 1997 the Australian Council for Educational Research conducted a test of reading skills. It showed that effectively 81 per cent of the indigenous sample failed those tests at year 3 level compared with 27 per cent of the main sample, and that 77 per cent of indigenous students at year 5, compared to 29 per cent of the non-indigenous population, failed that test. The situation is worst in remote areas. In particular, I draw people's attention to the Katherine region of the Northern Territory. The literacy survey in that region has exposed functional literacy levels of just seven per cent among indigenous students compared with 70 per cent for the general population.

Let us have a look at higher education. Despite increasing numbers of Aboriginal students enrolled, there is a 56 per cent dropout rate which depletes their ranks by the end of their first year, according to a 1996 report. This compares with 24 per cent for the general population and 25 per cent for the migrant population. I am sure there may well be triumphant notes from across this chamber later in the debate about the increased numbers of indigenous people actually enrolling in higher education and TAFE courses to the tune of around 3,000 nationally. But that figure conceals the fact that just under half of those enrolments are in bridging programs and students are often beamed up from secondary school in an attempt to get them into tertiary education.

With secondary school education, a 1994 survey showed that nearly half of indigenous people aged 15 and over had either received no formal education or had reached year 10 level, and that the year 10 certificate was the highest qualification achieved by 30 per cent of our indigenous people. The retention rates for indigenous students are poor. In 1996 the apparent indigenous retention rates compared quite unfavourably with that of non-indigenous students. Seventy-four per cent of indigenous students attend year 11 compared with 84 per cent of non-indigenous students, and only 29 per cent of indigenous students compared with 72 per cent of non-indigenous students complete year 12.

In the Northern Territory the situation is a national disgrace. There are no remote communities that provide secondary schooling to indigenous students. Someâand very fewâprovide post-primary education to students out bush. But by and large, those people who live in the central parts of this country in the Northern Territory and in the Top End need to travel to either Alice Springs or Darwin to attend boarding school for their secondary education. During this time that means that they are separated not only from their family but from their land and their culture. It is not surprising that many teenagers and their families are not prepared to make this move. In 1996 only one Aboriginal person in Central Australia completed year 12. Former Senator Bob Collins is currently conducting a review of Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory and that review will be welcomed when it is handed down. In the process of conducting that review he has said that a 15- or 16-year-old Aboriginal student leaving a rural school has the literacy ability of only a six or seven year old.

So why are we at this point? Federal governments have implemented an Aboriginal education program, known as IESIP, where millions of dollars have been handed out to state and territory governments each year. Let us have a look in particular at the Northern Territory government and its handling of that money. Through the estimates process we have discovered that 48 per cent of those funds are hived off by the Northern Territory government under the guise of administrative costs.

talk.start.para: âThat is just a disgrace.

âYes, an absolute disgrace. We have been given a breakdown of those costs. In estimates I have actually pursued vigorously why it is we reached 48 per cent. Quite a significant percentage of that goes to capital and expenditure upgrade and housing maintenance. I fail to understand why the federal government has not called the Northern Territory government to task over the misuse of this money. For example, why was the Northern Territory government the last government in this country out of the state and territory governments to produce performance indicators for the current Aboriginal education program agreement that they signed? In fact, as late as only a couple of months ago, it produced performance indicators under that agreement.

speech.para: ATSIC pointed out in their submission to Bob Collins during his review that they believe the Northern Territory government was contravening the indigenous education agreement entered into with the Commonwealth for the third triennium from 1997 to 1999. During a recent Senate committee inquiry travelling around Central Australia we discovered that other state and territory governments take off only 20 per cent of the funds for administrative costs. Yet the Northern Territory government has continued year after year to go unchecked, unaccounted for and blatantly misusing and misdirecting these funds for some other purpose. It has made a commitment to the progressive introduction of indigenous language teaching in more schools over the current triennium, but we are all too aware in this chamber of its recent decision to abolish the bilingual education program in the Northern Territory. As part of the AEP contract, a specific performance indicator was included which dealt with the need for the Northern Territory government to make indigenous language accessible within the educational experiences of indigenous children. As the triennium finishes in 1999, the Northern Territory government will be required to negotiate a set of achievable targets with the Commonwealth.

Let us have a look at what they have done with bilingual education, before I turn very quickly to the recent changes in Abstudy. On 1 December last year the Northern Territory Minister for Education and Training, Peter Adamson, announced the decision to cut bilingual education programs and to replace them with English as a second language program. Bilingual programs have run in the Northern Territory for 26 years. They operate at 17 of the 91 remote Aboriginal schools and during 1998 around 47 per cent of all students were enrolled in community schools operating a formal bilingual program.

You may well ask what that has to do with indigenous retention rates and indigenous performance rates in education. You need to realise that communities in the Northern Territory who have bilingual education have requested it. They have wanted it. It has been an initiative of those communities and was first introduced 26 years ago. What is important about that is the technique and methodology used in those bilingual schools. It is far easier for students in those schools to be able to understand the mechanics of literacy, reading and writing when they first learn that in their own language, then to translate those skills into English or into a second language. It is done in New Zealand and it is done comprehensively throughout America.

There is no evidence to suggest that those Aboriginal schools in the Territory with a total English curriculum are achieving any better rates. In fact, under the MAP tests used by the Northern Territory government, there is evidence to show that some bilingual schools perform better than some of the completely English schools in some of the urban areas. There has been no evidence to show that bilingual education is not working. In their submission to the review into Aboriginal education, ATSIC said:
. . . bilingual education forms an integral component of the educational aspirations of many Aboriginal parents in relation to their children's schooling.

That is something that parents across this country would all want. We all demand at some stage, as our the children go through school, an input into the kind of education and the quality of education they receive. The submission further said:
ATSIC recommends that, in line with the local, national and international support for the program, the Aboriginal Education Review Team consider this issue in detail as part of the Review Process.

Mandawuy Yunupingu stated in an article in Time magazine on 22 February 1999 that he believes the decision to discard bilingual education will hasten the demise of fragile Aboriginal languages and the culture they underpin. He says:
It's assimilation born again. It takes away from our people the power to do the empowering.

Oxfamâthe network of international aid agencies, which includes Community Aid Abroadâclaims in its report titled Education now: break the cycle of poverty that the decision to abolish bilingual education represents a clear breach of government obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. An aspect of that convention talks about protecting and respecting the rights of indigenous people.

So we have a decision by the Northern Territory government to abolish its bilingual programs which is a clear breach of the International Declaration on Human Rights, the Universal Declaration on Linguistic Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the international covenants on economic, social and cultural rights and civil and political rights. What have we seen from the government? Nothing. No comment and no attempt by Minister Kemp to pull the Northern Territory government into line and get it to reconsider its decision to abolish bilingual education.

There has been no comment on the subject and no meetings with the Northern Territory government. There have been no questions about accountability, and no evidence or proof that bilingual education is not happening. There has been inaction and silence from members of the government when there is clear evidence that it is not bilingual education that is the cause of some of the problems inherent in Aboriginal communities. What is happening? Bob Collins, in conversations that I have had with him, has said that the problems in Aboriginal communities are complex and that there are major issues that do not just go to the kinds of programs, the nature of programs or the delivery of programs.

Luke Slattery in an article in the Australian in November of last year very aptly describes the situation. His article is headed `No year 12 joy for Aborigines'. I have already explained to the Senate that in 1996, in Central Australia, only one person completed year 12. I think Luke Slattery sums up the situation when he talks about Aboriginal students being on a `slippery dip' that begins with chronic truancy, drug abuse, crime, youth suicide, life-term unemployment and domestic violence within their communities. That is at the heart of where things are wrong in terms of Aboriginal education in this country. That is coupled with a lack of accountability by state and territory governments in terms of what they do with their money and, of course, inexplicable changes to the support network provided by government, as we now see with the current Abstudy changes.

Let us have a look at those changes because they are all part of the melting pot that ensures that these kids on this slippery dip, as Luke Slattery puts it, are pushed down the slide at a faster rate. The Abstudy changes imply that the federal government is abandoning its equity targets for indigenous Australians in the tertiary sector. The changes will result in more than $18 million being cut from the Abstudy budget. The changes will expose a gap in student support at the state and territory level as indigenous students seek safety net alternatives to Abstudy assisted education.

An analysis regarding the changes to Abstudy was undertaken by the Institute of Koorie Education at Deakin University. It was commissioned and released on behalf of ATSIC. The study found that the changes, which are due to take effect on 1 January next year, will benefit fewer than 1,000 young and single students, who represent a small proportion of the total Abstudy student population. On the other hand, they will significantly disadvantage more than 14,000 indigenous students in the tertiary sector. This is amidst a climate, which I have outlined, of where indigenous students are not participating and are not succeeding in our education system. The government has decided to drive another nail in the coffin in terms of its changes to Abstudy.

Mature age students make up about 80 per cent of the TAFE and university indigenous student population in Australia. The majority of these mature age students are women who, in turn, make up almost half the total TAFE and university Abstudy population. What is it about the changes to Abstudy that pushes ATSIC to make these announcements and for Gatjil Djerrkura to make the kinds of statements he has made? The main problem behind the Abstudy changes are that they just do not recognise where Aboriginal people are at in terms of their study and in terms of what is happening with them.

Pushing the Abstudy changes into alignment with the Youth Allowance and the Newstart Allowance, as this change will do, does not recognise that the majority of Aboriginal students in TAFE and tertiary education do not get there after year 12. It does not recognise the fact that Aboriginal people tend to enter the TAFE and tertiary education sector long into their mature age life. They do not reach years 11 and 12; the figures show that. They re-enter the education experience when they are adults, when they are in a situation where they are either having or have had a family and their community supports them.

The changes to Abstudy do not recognise the way in which Aboriginal people choose to study or can study in this nation. Aboriginal students do not simply move off the track of year 12 into tertiary education; there is a significant break at that period of time. These changes do not recognise that. From a firm base of community and family support and direction, mature age indigenous students undertake further study, not straight after year 12, and it is study that is most connected to qualifications that contribute to their community's development and autonomy. The changes to Abstudy next year will in fact diminish the effectiveness of this study support scheme in terms of its continuing contribution to indigenous community developmentâas determined in the past by the members of these communities themselves through their participation in further study.

The impact of the changes to Abstudy in 2000 will be a sharp decline in the overall enrolment figures in TAFE and university courses by mature age indigenous students. From the total savings and costs calculated from the data analysed, the reduction to the Abstudy budget will be as high as $18 million in the year 2000 at 1 January and about $18.8 million by March of the same year. But the effect of that in the long term is that people will not be able to afford to return to study. If you push it in line with the Youth Allowance and Newstart it simply reduces the amount of money that these people will be paid. It reduces the financial support for those indigenous community members most ready and equipped to contribute to their community's economic, social and political determination.

The research project conducted by ATSIC considered the matter of alternative programs of support for the categories of students and found that they will be disadvantaged by the Abstudy changes in the year 2000. The key finding relevant to this matter is that these alternative programs, where they exist, will not act as a safety net for the losers from the changes to Abstudy. So we have perhaps a jigsaw puzzle of indigenous education in this country: we have bilingual education being cut and we have misuse of funds under IESIP by state and territory governmentsâin particular, the Northern Territory government. We have low retention rates. We have students who cannot make it through the system and complete years 11 and 12, and now, to top it all off, we have an attack on the tertiary system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to also speak on this general business matter. I am a little curious as to why this has been brought up at this point in time. In the Senate we currently have a major inquiry into indigenous education. The inquiry has completed its hearings and we are about to draft a report. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs is about to announce a very comprehensive review and redirection of the Aboriginal education program, with greater resources and higher emphasis on cooperation between the state, territory and federal governmentsâI will outline that a little later. Also, I find this curious in light of the sweep of national events that are on at the moment and in terms of the Labor Party's record on indigenous education.

speech.para: The record of the Labor Party showed that, after 13 years of government, 80 per cent of year 3 students could not read adequately, 70 per cent of year 3 students could not write adequately and 75 per cent of year 5 students could not read or write adequately. So, having had 13 years to have a go at this problem, the record of the Labor Party is absolutely abysmal. It was that very poor record which the Senate inquiry went out to examine. We went out to see what was the actual state of indigenous education and what measures we felt were necessary to try to improve the situation.

We moved right across the country, although the Labor Party showed their great interest in this matter by trying to truncate the inquiry. We did not go to two states, and they actually wanted to cut out Western Australia as well.

talk.start.para: âThat is not true.

âYes, it is, Senator. It is very true. It is true that there was an enormous amount of resistance to extending the inquiry to see Western Australia. It was only through a protracted period of negotiation with Senator Carr that we actually managed to get to Western Australia. I am very glad we did, because I found that leg of the inquiry probably the most informative of all. How could you leave out that state, given that two per cent of the Australian population is indigenous while in Western Australia it is six per cent? So how could you leave out a state like that? Yet that is what the Labor Party wanted to do.
âThat is a misrepresentation.

âSenator, if you had turned up to the Senate committee meetings and spent as long as I did negotiating this matter, you would know it was very true. There is some good news on indigenous education. A lot of people take the view that not much progress is being made, but the reality is that there has been, in a number of areas, a considerable amount of progress. One of the things that we were reviewing in particular was the implementation of the Aboriginal education policy from 1989âand therefore the review was timely as a 10-year benchmark on how that program had been progressing. We did find a very patchy record. There were improvements in quite a wide range of areas but there was also movement backwards in a number of othersâhence the need for us at this time to refocus on indigenous education policy and see if we can improve some of the educational outcomes.

speech.para: We did cover a very wide area of Australia. As I have mentioned a few minutes ago, we finally got to Western Australia, where we went to Kalgoorlie and Geraldton. In the Northern Territory, we went to Alice Springs and to a number of settlements up to 400 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs. We went into the Torres Strait Islands and also into Northern Queensland, to Weipa, Townsville and Cairns. We went to Adelaide and into western New South Wales, to Brewarrina and Bourke. That range of locations helped us to gain quite a good assessment of where the problems were in terms of indigenous education and what some effective strategies to address this matter might be.

We did find overall on the inquiryâand there is considerable evidence in the Hansard transcripts of that inquiry to back this upâthat indigenous participation rates in all forms of education have improved. This has been an upward trend since 1986. The proportion of indigenous people aged 15-plus with a qualification has increased in all categories. There has been a 40 per cent increase in indigenous school enrolments, and that trend has been going up since 1991. It has gone up over that time from 72,000 to 102,100 in 1998. VET enrolments have almost doubled, and that has been an upward trend since 1994, going from 23,000 to 44,500 in that time.

There has been a 60 per cent increase in higher education enrolments, and that has been an upward trend since 1991, moving from 4,800 to 7,700. I think that is one of the heartening trends: the leaders of this coming generation of indigenous people are moving into the higher levels of education at a much more rapid rate than they have in the past. When I was a senior lecturer at a university, I noted that trend starting very much in the late 1980s, and we set up an Aboriginal unit to assist the students there with tertiary study. They were moving into a whole range of faculties, including groundbreaking work in the field of medicine. We had at Newcastle the first Aboriginal graduates in medicine, and that trend has continued since that time.

The other areas where there has been an improvement over recent times relate to both primary and secondary education, and again the trends have been upward over the past 10 years. Primary school participation rates for indigenous children are now approaching those for non-indigenous children. They have moved up to 82.4 per cent in 1996. The non-indigenous rate is 87.9 per cent, and so that gap has closed quite considerably. In secondary schools, participation has been slowly improving. It has been moving up off a lower base: 54.3 per cent in 1986 to 60.5 per cent now, compared with a non-indigenous participation rate of 84.4 per cent. So there have been considerable improvements in a number of areas. There have been, as our inquiry found, advances in some areas and not much movement in others.

We now come to a time when we have some considerable challenges still before us, despite those improvements that I have outlined. In terms of secondary education, although the numbers involved in secondary education have gone up considerably, we still have problems with the completion rate, particularly through to the end of year 12. We have just under one-third of Aboriginal students staying through to year 12. Less than 20 per cent of year 3 indigenous students are meeting reading standards. The year 12 indigenous students' retention rate is less than half that for non-indigenous students. Indigenous students are less likely to achieve a post-school qualification. Qualified indigenous people have higher unemployment rates at all qualification levels, and indigenous students are absent from school more often than are non-indigenous students. So there are challenges before us.

Over the past three years, the federal government has moved to meet these challenges by increasing the resources that it is putting into indigenous education. Funding has been increased by $100 million across education portfoliosâ$100 million above the funding in Labor's last year of government. Estimated total spending is now $338 million for the years 1999-2000, compared with $288 million in Labor's last year of government. This funding is for Abstudy, the VET sector, higher education, the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program and the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Programâone of the programs that Senator Crossin referred to a little earlier on.

In the 1999-2000 budget, there is provision for more than $1.1 billion over the next five years to provide programs to improve educational opportunities for young indigenous Australians. Funding for indigenous education will remain at record levels for at least the next five years. The budget provides for an additional $71 million over the next five years to improve indigenous education provision, on top of the existing programs of spending. Funding for the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program will be boosted by $50 million over the next five years, and funding for the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program will be boosted by $2 million in 1999-2000 to a total of $62.2 million.

Since coming to government, the coalition has recognised that there are challenges and has committed extra resources, but there is more that needs to be done. Particularly as we move towards reconciliation, we are going to make very determined efforts to improve the gains that have been made already in this area. Achieving educational equality for indigenous Australians remains one of the principal educational challenges that still face us. All Australians have a right to an education which allows them to choose from the same range of opportunities, and it is within our capacity as a nation and as a government to ensure that the rights of indigenous Australians are met. This achievement will secure a stronger, more united and more reconciled Australia.

Over the past 30 years, despite some public perceptions to the contrary, there has been considerable progress. There is a perception that public expenditure on indigenous educa tion has not been achieving its goals and that, for many indigenous children, English is not only a second language but also a foreign language. There are problems of poor health, low self-esteem, the breaking up of families and communities and the demise of indigenous languages. These contribute further to these perceptions.

It has become clear over time that extra funding and resources cannot be relied on alone to achieve educational equality. Despite the commitment of all Australian governments to deliver educational equality, there is considerable variation in the overall pattern of improvement across government systems to the extent that progress at the national level is difficult to report. As we moved across the different states, we certainly saw evidence of those different patterns. Standards of educational infrastructure and service delivery to indigenous students vary greatly across the country. One of the great challenges is to bring these up to standard in some of the more remote areas of Australia. That is why, in our view, the government is now embracing a new, energetic and forward looking approach to the whole issue of equity. We believe that this is not a generational thing but something that can be achieved in a short time with the right strategies.

The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, is in the process of finalising a comprehensive strategy that will make significant inroads into closing the gap in educational outcomes between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians by the year 2004. Given that there have been ministerial council meetings on this until now, I am surprised that this motion has come before the Senate today. The Commonwealth government regards as unacceptable the continuance of significant educational inequality among different groups of Australians and rejects the view that the achievement of educational equality for indigenous Australians must necessarily be seen in the long term.

I believe that, as a government and as educators, we have the tools available to markedly accelerate achievement in educational equality over the next five yearsâthe target set by Dr Kemp. The approach has a number of elements and will be spearheaded by a national strategy on indigenous attendance, literacy and numeracy. The minister proposes to launch it later this year. The approach will reach agreement at a national council level through the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs, MCEETYA. This council will resolve national education policies and related issues, including the development of an enhanced mechanism for national reporting and the development and implementation of high quality standards in education infrastructure and service delivery to indigenous students.

The national literacy, numeracy and attendance strategy symbolises the government's resolve to accelerate the pace of change and make significant progress in closing the gap between the learning outcomes of indigenous and non-indigenous students by the year 2004. We intend, in this strategy, to link the achievements of educational equality to the national reconciliation process and require that education providers who are funded through the Commonwealth government's supplementary indigenous programs from 2001 to 2004 focus on accelerating the closure of the gaps between indigenous and non-indigenous students in educational outcomes in literacy, numeracy and attendance. Given the comments of the head of ATSIC which triggered this motion from Senator Carr, I think the opposition would certainly welcome this government initiative. We may be able to achieve with this strategy something that they could not achieve in their time.

Work is well advanced in preparing each of the elements of the strategy. We have won a commitment from all state and territory ministers of education to make the achievement of educational equality for indigenous Australians an urgent national priority. In reaching the decision in April this year, the ministers also established a task force on indigenous education, chaired by the Commonwealth, to report by early in the year 2000. Australia now has a stable national policy environment on indigenous education, and we intend to build significantly on this. In April of this year, all ministers reaffirmed that, consistent with previous decisions regarding the national literacy and numeracy benchmarks, all indigenous Australians leaving primary school should be numerate and be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level and every indigenous child who commenced school in 1998 should achieve minimum acceptable literacy and numeracy standards within four years.

The shift to national standards in the reporting of educational outcomes has exposed indigenous education problems at their source and revealed the barriers that need to be overcome to achieve educational equality for indigenous Australians. The MCEETYA task force is identifying a range of related issues and will provide appropriate advice to the ministerial council for the strategies for implementing this in the year 2000. I certainly hope the opposition will join us in supporting this type of approach.

We have the opportunity at last, through the leadership of Dr Kemp, to create a national framework for Aboriginal education. We have the opportunity to implement a cooperative federal model to actually achieve this. The objectives and the goals are commendable, the time frame is achievable and to improve on educational outcomes and help Aboriginal people achieve their aspirations will be one of the greatest steps we can take towards Aboriginal reconciliation .

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on this motion about retention rates for indigenous Australians in our schools. Anyone who has anything to do with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education will know that the concerns that Mr Djerrkura expressed this week are very real, but they will also know that solutions are not easy. The Senate education committee, as Senator Tierney said, has just completed the hearing stage of its inquiry into indigenous education. I would hope that the recommendations of that inquiry can show us some way forward. Senator Crossin rightly complains about reductions in Abstudy and the bilingual program in the Northern Territory, but I hope today's debate does not just come down to political point scoring. I think this issue deserves a tripartisan approach, and it is not a matter that either party in government can claim to have had all the answers to.

speech.para: I do not believe there is an education issue in this country which is as complex as this one. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their relationships with education are as diverse as could possibly be imagined. The education experience at Badu Island in the Torres Strait is very different from that at Weipa, Kalgoorlie, Maningrida or Yuendumu, and the list goes on.

Some of the issues which work against the best efforts of educators are health, language, remoteness, poverty, social dislocation, the cultural inappropriateness of our school system, the lack of jobs and prospects, post-secondary schools for Aboriginal children, community attitudes to education, incarceration rates, alcohol abuse and racial discrimination. Just a couple of weeks ago in Kalgoorlie, I spoke with the head of the education council, an Aboriginal man, in that community. He told me his education was a good one, but his sacrifice for that was being one of the stolen children. He had been taken as a two-year-old from his family and educated in the mission at Kalgoorlie, not knowing that he had three brothers and sisters in the same place. He was left at the age of 13 to fend for himself. He was sent off into the wide world with nobody to support him. So, whilst his education may have been a reasonably good one, he sacrificed a great deal for that. He told me that many of his fellow children from the community from which he was taken ended up being those who were on the fringes of society, had serious alcohol problems and suffered from very early death rates.

There are enormous problems for teachers, too. Those indigenous people who have been trained as teachers are often snapped up by government departmentsâthey seem to be the worst offenders. If these people return to remote communities, there is no special consideration for them. For housing, for instance, many will be forced into crowded dwellings which make it very difficult, if not impossible, for them to cope with the work which is needed out of school hours and to perform as teachers in communities. There are indigenous teachers, particularly females, who do not have authority over some skin groups and especially some boys, particularly those who have been through initiation. Indigenous teacher aides are absolutely essential in many of the schools the committee visited. They are essential to make these places welcoming for indigenous students. Yet there is no career path for these teachers and the wages are very low. In some schools they are treated very differently from white teachers; they do not have access to staff rooms and the like. In a number of the schools we visited, indigenous people were utilised in schools through CDEP projects. That seemed to be very successful in most places, although, again, the income for those people is extremely low and would hardly allow them to be able to build their own houses or live in a manner which we take for granted.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I recall that you and I visited a very small and remote community up in Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory called Jimarda where there were indigenous teachers. They said to us that their biggest problem was that the visiting white teacher did not come often enough. When we quizzed them on why this was a problem, it seemed that, during the times when there was no white teacher there for a range of reasons, those teachers had no authority within the community. We also heard, as I recall, that the white teacher who came a few times a month was a very young woman. She drove from Maningrida to Jimarda, which is a very long distance, and she brought with herâas well as many of the provisions required by that communityâa tent, and that was where she stayed when she was in that place. I could imagine that, in an environment where there were no services, running water or electricity, this would, indeed, be a very harsh environment in which to teach. Often the white teachers who are sent to these remote communities are very young and inexperienced, and in some places they find themselves being head teachers in small schools.

The committee discovered that there are still schools which bring students into the school. They shower, clothe and feed them and, as far as possible, they integrate them into what is largely a white school environment. Schools are trying a range of measures to keep children in school. Some schools are collecting children every day, often providing them with breakfasts and other support. Others say that this is simply taking the responsibility away from the parents and is not, in the long term, sustainable and that the question of getting children to school needs to be a collective responsibility of the community. The fact remains that you cannot teach hungry children. So, one way or the other, for the sake of those children we need to make sure that they are able to function effectively within the classroom.

A school just out of Geraldton has an annexe, which apparently is funded by a generous benefactor I think from Victoria. This annexe provides children at that primary school with meals, health services and clothingâif that is what is needed by the children who attend. It is up to those children to refer themselves to this annexe, and they can do that quite comfortably. That is where they get the sort of support that children in so many families in this country take for granted. This school has solved, for instance, the problem of scabies, which affected the whole community, by teaching very young children how to treat this ultimately life threatening disease.

If one thing is clear to me it is that we have to have a holistic approach to Aboriginal education: housing, health, sanitation and nutrition must all be improved. Children cannot learn if they are distracted by unbearably itchy skin, by blocked sinuses and by nits. And they cannot learn if they cannot hear, and so many indigenous children are deaf from infections in their respiratory and olfactory areas. If glue sniffing is rife, then these children may have already damaged their brains. Returning to the issue of scabies, I recall going into the community health centre in Jabiru and asking what the most serious health problem was amongst the Aboriginal community and it was scabiesâ95 per cent of children and therefore their families had scabies.
In all of the committee's travels, I do not recall seeing one indigenous child with reading glasses. One reason might be that their eyesight is very good, but I somehow doubt that that is the case.

Aboriginal children are very shy and often they come to school with no English at all. There are few schools in remote areas with specialist ESL teachers, yet English is for many of these children their second, their third, their fourth and even their fifth language. The obstinate Northern Territory government is closing down bilingual programs in spite of the very obvious success of those programs, and that is highly regrettable. However, there is some good work being done in South Australia. There are nine languages and there is some degree of teaching material prepared for schools in four of those languages. That is quite considerable, I understand. That is from a total of 50 languages that were once spoken in South Australia.

I found it extraordinary to go into largely Aboriginal schools and hear principals tell us that they were expected to deliver LOTE programsâlanguages other than Englishâand in many places the designated language was Indonesian, which was extraordinary, given that the language of the Aboriginal community of the area was not spoken. It seems a great pity to me that white students in this country have not learnt an Aboriginal language. I understand that that happens to just a handful of children in some schools, but it is still very rare, just as it is rare for white teachers to speak an Aboriginal language.

I recall even as a child in this country that New Zealand Maoris would arrive and put on programs for primary school children and we all trotted along to those programs and oftentimes learned words from indigenous languages in New Zealand, yet none of us knew any words from indigenous languages in this country. There are indigenous groups who do not want their languages taken up by white people and taught to their children in schools, but in other communities they very much want that to happen.

At a school in the Central Desert there was a preschool program that I recall which concentrated on oral English, and children who went through that year of preschool were very much more successful in subsequent years in primary school. But the complaint from the school was that they were operating this program on a grant and there was no guarantee that they would be able to employ that teacher, who was developing great expertise in this area, the following year. School after school told the committee about their endless search for money and grant applications.

Federal initiatives to set up homework programs were a great success in some areas and completely useless in other areas where students saw them as a form of detention and there was very little involvement. Some schools, we heard, use that money creatively to find other ways of assisting Aboriginal students to study.

The committee went into some schools in even quite remote areas which were well equipped, neat and tidy and others which were in serious states of disrepair. We heard that many of these schools had enormous difficulty in attracting any funds for capital works. There was one school in particular where there was not even adequate electricity to put the lights on in every classroom and have an air conditioner going in the staffroom at the same time. It seemed to me to be very puzzling the way in which money for capital works, which is largely federal money, is divvyed up amongst school communities and a lot of that seemed to have something to do with the sort of politics in the town.

The problems, as I said initially, are extremely complex in this area. I do not want to pre-empt the report, which the education committee will deliver shortly, but I hope this will lead the way forward and help us to improve the outcomes for indigenous students. There can be no doubt that there must be more indigenous teachers and we must find a way of taking teacher training closer to them in their communities. There is no doubt in my mind either that schools must be made more culturally appropriate. Many schools are still run on a largely white line, and we must be more creative with the way we make these schools comfortable for students to come into and thrive.

Finally, I think the lesson which is also very clear from the work the committee has done is that communities must be involved in decision making in the school. Those schools we saw that were doing better than others all had that very important community involvement in decision making. They were part of school committees and they were very much enthusiasts for education, and that is important in passing on to communities the importance of education for young people.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on this motion to draw the Senate's attention to the disastrous state of indigenous education and the concern about the government's proposed changes to Abstudy. In the motion, Mr Djerrkura's quote was in response to a release of an ATSIC commissioned report entitled Analysis of the proposed changes to Abstudy on indigenous students . The report was commissioned by ATSIC through open tender and was won by the Institute of Koori Education and the Research Institute for Professional and Vocational Education and Training from Deakin University, along with the Gordon Institute of TAFE. These institutes are regarded as highly respected organisations, respected for their understanding of the complexities of indigenous education and for their methodology. They can and should be regarded as providing an independent and authoritative evaluation of the proposals. The results from the report are very concerning, and I can understand Mr Djerrkura's concerns which are the subject of this motion.

speech.para: The report's terms of reference essentially were to assess the impacts of the changes to the Abstudy arrangements and to ascertain if other programs will fill the gaps caused by those impacts. The findings of the report, as I said, are very concerning. The benefit will be only to a very small number of people in the Aboriginal education communityâthose who are young and single. In 1998, there were 730 students who were Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander and who were under 21 and 165 students who were single and living at home. Those are the students who will benefit from these proposed changes.

The clear majority of students will be disadvantaged. As Senator Crossin has described, those students particularly who will be disadvantaged are the mature age students, who make up 80 per cent of TAFE and university students, and most of those are women. Fifteen per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander TAFE and university students are mature age and on sole parent pensions, and 3,045 of those types of students will be disadvantaged. Those people who are most likely to undertake tertiary education are mature age students with family responsibilities. This demographic does not fit the non-indigenous, largely middle-class pattern of access to higher education, which, it would seem, is the model being used by the government in its aligning of access to support for students, whether they be indigenous or non-indigenous.

The report identifies that, in the year 2000, up to $18.1 million may be lost from indigenous student support and, further, that existing programs will not act as a safety net for those whose access to financial support is diminished. What was the government's response? Essentially, as we heard the other day in question time, it was to shoot the messenger. In question time on Tuesday, Senator Herron accused the report of working from inaccurate figures. He said:

The . . . report contains a number of incorrect assumptions and has, in many cases, extrapolated too much from insufficient data. The breakdown of affected populations is inaccurate and the calculation of financial gain or loss resulting from the changes for certain student population groups is not correct.

My advice is that the authors were very careful to check the alignments they were making between Abstudy as it currently exists and as it will exist with Youth Allowance and Newstart. I am advised that the authors used DETYA sample data to derive the number of students in each category. The sample provided was directly from DETYA's own statistics. The actual sample was two-thirds of the total population of Abstudy tertiary beneficiaries in 1998, and it matched the key characteristics of the total Abstudy population. It is a significant sample and cannot be discounted. Senator Herron then said that the report was:
. . . flawed largely because of the premise that all students currently enrolled in courses will continue into 2000 . . .
I cannot understand his comment. Is he saying that, all of a sudden, we cannot predict the indigenous access to higher education? The evidence certainly does not support this.

Between 1986 and 1991, enrolments of indigenous students in higher education grew by 148.7 per cent compared with 28.3 per cent for the general population. As a proportion of total higher education enrolments, the number of indigenous students rose from 0.3 per cent in 1981 to 1.2 per cent in 1996. Year 12 retention rates for indigenous students rose four percentage points between 1992 and 1996 while they were falling for non-indigenous students. The indigenous retention rate is now 32.1 per cent compared with 72.7 per cent for the general population.

Whilst those figures are not brilliant, they show a steady increase. Since 1991, the growth of access of indigenous students to higher education has been steady. The only times when there have been glitches in this growth have been when there have been changes in support for access by indigenous students. The mid-1980s, when HECS was originally introduced, and 1997, when the first Abstudy changes were made, were the only times when that steady growth pattern was changed. This sensitivity to change clearly indicates that indigenous students are highly reliant on government support and respond to changes by removing themselves from study. Perhaps that is what Senator Herron meant when he said that we cannot predict participation rates in the year 2000 because that is when the changes to Abstudy will be effected.

I turn now to the impact of any loss of participation by indigenous students for our community. The final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody was released in April 1991. The report highlighted the lack of success in the formal education system to deliver equitable outcomes for Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders. The report inextricably linked education and training to the disproportionate representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians in custody.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody endorsed the 21 goals of the AEPâthe national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education programâestablished in 1990, and it emphasised the importance of the policy as a way of ensuring that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples achieve a greater degree of control over education services. The AEP sets out 21 long-term goals under the following aims: involvement of Aboriginal people in educational decision making, equitable access to educational services, equitable participation in education and equitable and appropriate education outcomes. A national review of the effectiveness of the AEP was held in 1993. The review showed that, although improvements had been made in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation and outcomes with regard to education and training, the improvements were inconsistent across sectors and between states and territories.

The Ministerial Council for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs established an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Task Force which developed the national strategy for the education of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, which Senator Tierney referred to earlier. At the ministerial council meeting in 1995, the commitment to the AEP was reaffirmed. In December 1995 the ministerial council endorsed the national strategy, established a number of priority areas and agreed to an outcomes focus for work in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education and training. The Commonwealth core national performance targets for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education and training focus on culturally inclusive education, attendance targets, retention rates and completion rates and are very similar to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

I am concerned, though, that the implementation of the changes to Abstudy will undermine the ability to attain those agreed retention rates and completion rates. The impacts on mature age students' access to higher education and the impacts on rural and remote students' access, who have to relocate in order to attend their study, are significant and real. In particular, I am concerned about female mature age students, who in many respects are the ones who will be the Aboriginal teachers who are so sought after in our state education systems. Those people have provided enormous breadth to the education system. They are, as I said, extremely sought after, and they are highly respected by students, both in rural and remote settings and in regional centres such as my own town.

I am also concerned for 140 people who will be significantly impacted by the changes to Abstudy. These people are elders who are currently enrolled in universities around Australia. They are currently receiving pensioner support payments as a part of their Abstudy, but they will lose those payments if they have to move into alignment with the mainstream support, as proposed by the changes to Abstudy.

These people offer so much to our education system. In fact, I think we receive more from them than they receive from attending their university. They are providing a link between their indigenous community and the education community. They are providing the validation of indigenous knowledge within the non-indigenous framework. Importantly, they are providing the leadership for appropriate curriculum development and design, which is so important to meet the first AEP goal of involving indigenous people in educational decision making. Many of these people study in the humanities sector and the natural resource management sector, and it would be an absolute tragedy if any of them were forced to remove themselves from the education system as a result of the Abstudy changes.

I would now like to move to what should be the model for dealing with, as Senator Allison said, a very difficult policy areaâthat is, making sure we can improve the access rates to education for indigenous people. It is true that, whether it be in education or health, where the government and the community work together, especially in indigenous affairs, the potential for maximising the outcomes is improved immeasurably.

I would like to commend a number of Queensland programs that were initiatives of the Queensland government and that have been very successful, in my view, in improv ing access for indigenous people. The first program is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Tertiary Aspirations Program, commonly called AITAP. It was developed in 1987 as a Queensland Department of Education initiative in conjunction with the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training on the recommendation of an organisation which has now moved on, the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Consultative Committee.

AITAP's vision is equity for and empowerment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people through success in educationâsomething I am sure we all agree with. AITAP has encouraged and inspired Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students from across Queensland to succeed in secondary schooling and to continue this success on to further study and careers. AITAP was developed to address low retention rates and subsequent low representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in tertiary courses.

In 1987 there were five pilot schools in the AITAP program; by 1998, this had grown to a total of 100 schools. They are drawn from primary and secondary schools, and they are in the government and non-government sectors. In 1997 the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Unit in Queensland assumed responsibility for the coordination of AITAP programs in schools.

The outcomes have been very significant. There has been an increase in the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in the AITAP program; there has been an increase in their capacity to participate in academic, social and cultural programs within the education system; and there have been enhanced socio-cultural and learning outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students who participate in the program.

The second program, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Careers Aspirations Pathways Program, is a more recent development. It was only developed in 1998 as an initiative of Education Queensland, once again in conjunction with DETYA. The program complements the AITAP program. Its aim is to achieve equivalence between indigenous and non-indigenous students in terms of their retention levels and also to provide enhanced pathways from school to tertiary education, TAFE or an apprenticeship or traineeship.

Once again, this collaborative approach to the issues facing indigenous people has been successful. There has been success at progressing the goal of enhanced educational outcomes. They have been measured by improved retention rates between year 7 and year 10âa very difficult periodâand then an increased retention rate to year 12.

I also want to very briefly compliment a small program operating at Cairns West State School in Cairns. It is named the Alternative Schools Program and is an excellent example of a bottom up, community based approach to solving the problem identified at that school of low attendance rates. The school worked with the Cairns City Council, the broader community and particularly the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community to first of all identify that there was a problem with children remaining at school and then ensure that the education being provided by the school was going to keep them there once we got them to go to school.

We have been able to establish an alternative school in a shopping centre close to the school. We have done that in Cairns West by cobbling together pieces of funding from all sorts of places, including the Cairns City Council. The results are excellent. I understand that the committee went to Cairns West State School when they were in Cairns recently but, unfortunately, it is an example of the community doing its job to solve a problem and getting very limited support from government. I reiterate that the way to solve these issues is for communities and governments to work together on identified problems and with agreed solutions. The Cairns West State School is where the community has had to take the burden by themselves.

I now return to the issue of the Abstudy changes and my concern at the motivation for the shift in the government's policy. Many commentators have seen the obvious similarities between the aligning of Abstudy to mainstream non-indigenous funding programs proposed by this government and the announcements by the former member for Oxley, who regularly said that indigenous students should not receive special benefits. She did not understand that people who are disadvantaged need extra support to overcome that disadvantage, and I would suggest that neither does this government if it continues to pursue changing the policy of Abstudy to limit access by the most disadvantaged Australians to education, which I, as a former teacher, believe is the key to their potential economic development.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak to this motion with somewhat of a feeling of superfluousness. I had the privilege of listening to Senator Tierney's excellent, comprehensive and well-balanced speech earlier on the matter of indigenous education and the problems faced and how we can look forward to try to resolve them. However, a number of other speakers also touched on other issues, and I believe that this requires us to reinforce what Senator Tierney has said. The problems presented by indigenous education are well recognised but, more importantly, they are not new problems. They have been around for many years. As indicated by the statement which prompted this motionâthat is, the statement by the ATSIC chairman referring to three decades of effortâindigenous people are still facing the same education shortfalls there were before.

speech.para: As this is a longstanding problem, we are obviously not looking at simple solutions to it. But before I get into that, let me again look at the magnitude of the problem. I will not quote other information, but I want to quote what ATSIC submitted to the Senate inquiries into indigenous education, and Senator Tierney has already referred to it. Their submission quoted a 1994 study which showed that nearly half of indigenous people aged 15 years and over had received no formal education or had reached year 10 level. Year 10 certificates were the highest education qualifications achieved by almost 30 per cent of indigenous people. Only one in six indigenous people had obtained qualifications after leaving school. The retention rate at that time was 33 per cent for indigenous students compared with 75 per cent for all students. While the respective figures have changed since thenâthat is, since 1994âin practical terms the gap is still quite huge. Finally, only 5.5 per cent of the indigenous school age population were participating in years 11 and 12. The participation rate for non-indigenous people was more than double this rate.

As Senator Crossin said, this situation is not just a problem; it is a national disgrace. It is important to recognise that it is a national disgrace because as a nation, as a community, we need to recognise that it requires a national effort to eradicate it. It is not an effort which can be made overnight and it cannot be done by any single party. So it is important to recogniseâand I urge senators on all sides to recognise thisâthat it requires a joint effort. All of us need to focus our minds on this effort.

I would like to make some comments on points that other speakers have raised. Firstly, we need to recognise that education is not a single stand-alone issue, especially in the case of the indigenous population. It is well recognised that many factors, including poverty, ill health and low self-esteem, contribute to the educational disadvantage of the indigenous people. However, from evidence given to the Senate committee inquiry I mentioned earlier, one of the major factors that many people have not recognised is that inadequacy in education can arise from having a low expectation of gaining a beneficial outcome from education. That can really discourage young people of the indigenous population from continuing their participation in the education process.

We need to look at indigenous education as a whole range of solutions rather than simply saying, `We have a low retention rate or we have low achievement, and therefore let us throw in some more money or focus in on this point and we will solve this problem.' Education must be recognised as part of the life cycle. Unless you have developed a knowledge of what education can mean to you in your life and also have some expectation of achieving those aims, no-one will participate in it.

One of the issues which Senator Crossin particularly raised and which Senator Allison also raised is that indigenous education seemed to be a particular problem in the Northern Territory. I think that is perhaps an unfortunate focus to be given on that, because education is not something where you can simply say, `We demand a particular result, otherwise we will not put any Commonwealth resources into it.' What Senator Crossin seemed to be suggesting was that the Northern Territory government had wasted or illegally diverted Commonwealth resources away from indigenous education.

However, that suggestion ignores the fact that education is not a Commonwealth responsibility. The Commonwealth has no facilities to actually provide education, even though the Commonwealth does have responsibility for the indigenous population. The Commonwealth can only purchase services from other providers, because any service provided directly from the Commonwealth may not meet local conditions. Senator Allison referred to a federal initiative of providing afterschool studies facilities. She mentioned that in some cases it was highly successful, but in other areas it was regarded as an imposition. That demonstrates how, over a large national population, a particular proposed solution might not be useful.

Another area, which other speakers have appeared to focus on concerns the proposed changes to Abstudy. This is also the basis of the statement by the ATSIC chairman, which this report is supposed to have shown, that the proposed changes would drastically disadvantage indigenous students. In fact, Senator McLucas characterises the federal government as shooting the messenger. But in this particular case it is not an accurate messenger: of course, shooting the messenger never solves the problem but, if the messenger brings you the wrong message, it is reasonable to banish the messenger from the service. In this case, this report started off on a biased footing: it is starting from the point that is critical of the government's decision to align the Abstudy payment, living allowance and pensioner education supplement with mainstream benefits.

The basic finding of this study claims that alternative programs of student support will not provide a safety net for Abstudy's losers and warns of widespread confusion in the community about indigenous education. But the simple fact that such a statement can be included in its conclusion indicates that it started off as a commentary rather than as a factual analysis. The ATSIC study also contained a number of inaccurate assumptions and has in many cases extrapolated too much from insufficient data. I know Senator McLucas said it was extrapolated from the government's data, but the problem with extrapolation from existing data is that the base dataâthe population dataâchanges all the time. It is not a fixed population.

In forecasting, it is always dangerous to take an existing situationâparticularly of a population, which can and does varyâand then project it forward. In all reputable forecasting processes, it is always necessary to regularly and frequently update your projection according to the changes in the base population. This report fails to do that. We believe that the breakdown of the affected population is inaccurate and that the calculation of the financial gains and losses that would result from the proposed changes for the student population is not correct. The conclusion about the financial impact of the proposed changesâthat the Abstudy budget could be reduced in 2000 by as much as $18.1 millionâis a fraud, largely because, as the minister reported to the Senate, the premise is that all students currently enrolled in courses will continue into 2000.

talk.start.para: âNext year!

âIt is a significant overestimation of the number of pensioner education supplement beneficiaries. I hear Senator McLucas criticise this particular comment. It is not a mistake to assume that the current student population will stay on into 2000, but the assumption is not just that the number of students will continue into 2000 but also that their conditions will remain the same into 2000. That is flawed. The report also emphasises the importance of changes to the pensioner education supplement but overestimates the number of pensioner education supplement recipients by 49.1 per cent, citing 7,900 recipients rather than the actual number of 5,297.

speech.para: The report acknowledges the availability of mainstream related entitlements such as rent assistance and the continued availability of Abstudy supplementary benefits. These considerations are not given due weight when determining the impact of changes, and the supplementary Abstudy payments are ignored in the comparison with youth allowance and Newstart. The forecast has to be varied according to changing conditions. No one set of forecasts should be taken as gospel. What do we do in this situation? I urge senators to consider that the government's policy relating to Abstudyâand other programs, as wellâis to focus on outcomes.

The government's policies are outcome driven rather than input driven. The purpose of indigenous education assistance programs is to emphasise key issues, such as literacy, numeracy, attendance and a greater involvement by parents and also by the children themselvesâin other words, by the whole indigenous communityâin indigenous education programs. The government is looking forward to a community involvement in the education program rather than just saying, `You are a student; you are not a student. If you are a student, you get particular support; if you are not a student, you do not get that support.' That is quite wrong.

We can only achieve the best results by getting the whole community involved, and that means a substantial change in how the community views education. This comes back to my comment earlier that you cannot use fixed data to forecast in changing conditions. Your criticism, Senator McLucas, of the minister's response is simplistic. I would refer to some of the examples Senator McLucas gave on the various successful programsâas she herself pointed outâin Queensland. Senator McLucas said that those programs had been successful because they had had community support and involvement. They were not simply cases of a government throwing money at the problem. Throwing money is never enough: you can keep on throwing money without ever achieving anything.
